Package ca.cgjennings.spelling.policy

Class AbstractWordPolicy

java.lang.Object
ca.cgjennings.spelling.policy.AbstractWordPolicy
All Implemented Interfaces:
PhoneticHashProvider, WordPolicy
Direct Known Subclasses:
AcceptPolicy, BasicPolicy, LocalePolicy, NoOpPolicy, PolicyChain
public abstract class AbstractWordPolicy extends Object implements WordPolicy
This abstract policy allows implementors to create a new policy with a minimum of effort.

  • Method Details

    • evaluate

      public Object evaluate​(String word)
      Evaluate a word under this policy. The policy can return the original string, causing the word to be checked normally. Alternatively, it can return a different string as a proxy word to be checked instead of the original word. Finally, it can return one of the special values Evaluation.REJECT_WORD or Evaluation.ACCEPT_WORD. These cause the word to immediately be either rejected as a misspelled word or accepted as a correctly spelled word, respectively. This implementation always returns the original word.
      Specified by:
      evaluate in interface WordPolicy
      Parameters:
      word - the word being checked by the caller
      Returns:
      the word to be looked up, or an Evaluation code

    • modifySuggestion

      public String modifySuggestion​(String word, String suggestion)
      Allows the policy to modify a suggested replacement before it is returned to the user if it wishes. This can be used in combination with WordPolicy.evaluate(java.lang.String) to transparently modify the words that are queried and fetched from the dictionary. For example, if the policy strips off affixes in evaluate, this method could be used to add the appropriate affixes back onto suggestion words so that the affixes on the suggestions agree with those of the mismatched word. If the policy does not wish to modify the suggestion, it should return suggestion unchanged. This implementation always returns the original suggestion.
      Specified by:
      modifySuggestion in interface WordPolicy
      Parameters:
      word - the word for which suggestions have been requested
      suggestion - a suggested replacement for the word
      Returns:
      the original suggestion or a replacement

    • getHint

      public Object getHint​(WordPolicy.Hint key)
      Return the value of a policy hint. If no specific value has been set, the default value will be returned.
      Specified by:

      Parameters:

      Returns:

    • hasPhonetics

      public boolean hasPhonetics()
      Return true if this policy can perform phonetic hashing. The AbstractWordPolicy implementation of this method returns false.
      Specified by:
      hasPhonetics in interface WordPolicy
      Returns:
      true if WordPolicy.getPhoneticHash(java.lang.String) is supported

    • getPhoneticHash

      public String getPhoneticHash​(String word)
      Return a hash code representing how a string is pronounced. This can be used to help rank spelling suggestions, so that words that sound more similar are favoured more highly.

      Policies that do not provide a phonetic hashing algorithm must throw UnsupportedOperationException. The AbstractWordPolicy implementation of this method always throws UnsupportedOperationException.

      Specified by:
      getPhoneticHash in interface PhoneticHashProvider
      Specified by:
      getPhoneticHash in interface WordPolicy
      Parameters:
      word - the word to obtain a hash code for
      Returns:
      the phonetic hash of the word
      See Also:
      WordPolicy.hasPhonetics()

    • getTypistErrorModel

      public TypistErrorModel getTypistErrorModel()
      Returns a model of keys that are frequently mistaken for each other while typing. This can be used to improve the quality of suggestions.
      Specified by:
      getTypistErrorModel in interface WordPolicy
      Returns:
      a model of common typing errors

    • getPhoneticCategory

      protected static char getPhoneticCategory​(char thisLetter, char nextLetter)
      This method returns a code to represent the phonetic category of a letter. Phonetic categories divide letters into groups based upon how they sound. Letters that produce similar sounds are placed in the same category.

      You may create up to 26 sound categories, from 'a' to 'z', although you will generally use far less. In addition, the following special categories are recognized by the algorithm:

      '?' : indicates that the category is unknown
      '-' : indicates that the letter is silent and should not be considered

      A basic implementation may base its decision on a single letter (thisLetter). More advanced implementations may also use nextLetter to provide additional context. This variable contains the value of the letter following thisLetter in the word, or the null character '\0' if there is no following letter.

      When the second letter is considered, you may wish to "consume" the second letter, so that the algorithm treats thisLetter and nextLetter as a single letter. That is, the algorithm will skip over nextLetter and the next call to this method will be for the letter following nextLetter in the word. To indicate that the second letter should be consumed, return the capitalized version of its category ('A'-'Z') or '=' if the letter pair is silent.

      The default implementation is suitable for phonetic analysis of English. It uses the following categories: 

       'o' : a, e, i, o, u, y 'k' : c, k, q 'z' : s, z 't' : d, t 'm' : m, n '-'
 : e at end of word

      The implemenation treats upper- and lower-case letters equally and converts common accents to their unaccented form. Letters not listed above form their own category. All other characters are converted to '?'.

      Parameters:
      thisLetter - the current letter being considered
      nextLetter - the following letter in the word, or '\0' if there is none
      Returns:
      a phonetic category for the letter or letter pair

    • standardizeLetter

      protected static char standardizeLetter​(char letter)
      Convert a letter to an uppercase equivalent, dropping common accents. This helper method may be useful when implementing getPhoneticCategory(char, char).
      Parameters:
      letter - the letter to standardize
      Returns:
      the standardized representation of the letter
